awd_titl_txt: Measuring the Objectivity and Bias of Experts
awd_abstract_narration:
Expert testimony is often a critical aspect of criminal and civil trials, in part because of perceived objectivity of experts and their expertise. Yet, individuals are susceptible to psychological biases that can compromise objective judgment and decision making, even if they are unaware of their own bias while recognizing it in others. If experts are similarly susceptible to bias, then their compromised objectivity could influence the outcome of trials, perhaps raising constitutional issues with respect to fair trials. This project will measure and document experts' perception of their own biases, as well as the consequences of their potential misperceptions of those biases. As a consequence, this project has the potential to inform actors in the legal system about ways to limit bias in expert decision making.

This project will employ surveys and experiments designed to document biases of experts, and their perception of those biases. Further, it will examine differences that experts and non-experts have with respect to their biases. The focus will be on experts in the legal field, including forensic mental health and fingerprint identification experts. The project will test the hypothesis of "bias blind spot," which is the tendency to recognize bias in others but not oneself. Thus, the project is designed to compare any bias blind spots of experts with that of non-experts. Surveys of experts and non-experts in various fields will be utilized to document experts' and non-experts' bias blind spots. Then, the project will employ experiments that measure experts' actual susceptibility to various biases and their awareness of those susceptibilities. The project also will investigate the consequences of exaggerated confidence in experts' objectivity. De-identified data from the project will be made publicly available.

por.por_cntn:
Do people (including experts themselves) have too much faith in the objectivity of expert judgment? People are vulnerable to a host of psychological biases that prejudice judgments and decisions. One might hope and expect experts to be more protected against these biases than the average person, yet the evidence supporting this expectation of expert objectivity is mixed at best. We investigated the degree to which experts view themselves as objective and the degree to which those perceptions are tethered to reality. Psychological scientists have identified a seemingly universal human tendency to be blind to one's own bias even while recognizing it in others (e.g., Pronin, Lin, & Ross, 2002; Pronin & Hazel, 2023), but experts' susceptibilities to this error have been little examined. Expert vulnerability to this "bias blind spot" - and laypeople's illusion of expert objectivity - could have serious consequences for society. Bias mitigating procedures (such as blinding decision makers to potentially biasing information) could solve some of these problems, but experts may be resistant to using these procedures if they are unduly confident in their immunity to bias. Consequences of an expert bias blind spot could therefore include misplaced confidence in expert judgment, hidden error or prejudice in experts' recommendations, and rejection of strategies that could mitigate bias. Of course, there also are costs to overestimating experts' biases, such as placing unnecessary restrictions on expert judgment, thus making this problem particularly important to study.

Across multiple preregistered studies with different methods and in different decision domains, we find robust evidence that (1) experts can be vulnerable to predictable and systematic cognitive biases even in their professional judgments and decisions, (2) experts' perceptions are generally not tethered well to the reality of their biases (i.e., experts exhibit a bias blind spot), (3) laypeople tend to believe experts are protected against bias (i.e., people have an illusion of expert objectivity), and (4) there are real consequences for expert bias blindness and people's illusion of expert objectivity, with clear policy relevance.

Specifically, regarding (1), expert vulnerability to actual cognitive bias: In a large, ecologically-valid preregistered experiment with psychologist expert participants, we find clear evidence of anchoring effects in clinical judgments of a defendant's psychopathy (which could have real-world consequences in legal settings, such as bearing on judges' determinations in capital sentencing hearings). In addition, experts also largely sought to expose themselves to biasing information in behavioral choice points during the experiment.

Regarding (2), experts' perceptions of their susceptibility to bias: Data from the experiment described in the previous paragraph found that experts exhibited a bias blind spot, such that they believed their peers' judgments were much more affected by the anchoring bias than their own, and that their peers were in general more susceptible to bias in their professional judgments than they themselves were. In other studies from this project from different expert domains, we showed that experts believe bias influences themselves less than other experts in their own field, and especially less than experts in other fields. Thus, the bias blind spot phenomenon among experts appears to be robust.

Regarding (3), laypeople's perceptions of expert objectivity: In a large study of laypeople's perception of expert objectivity and performance across 18 expert domains (selected for good variability across dimensions underpinning real expertise), people perceived experts as reasonably protected from bias. Participants viewed the two types of forensic experts as the most objective, despite those representing the most and least reliable domains of forensic science according to the National Academy of Sciences (2009). Third and fourth on the list were heart surgeons and commercial airline pilots, with restaurant critics perceived as least objective and stock brokers second-to-last. In the middle were clinical psychologists, CIA intelligence analysts, and state court judges. On the whole, people were overconfident in the objectivity of some types of experts, particularly forensic experts.

Regarding (4), consequences of exaggerated confidence in experts' objectivity: we found clear evidence that experts' bias blind spot and laypeople's illusion of expert objectivity underlie resistance to bias mitigating procedures. Experts (especially those with more experience and those with larger bias blind spots) were more resistant to policies and procedures that reduce bias, like blinding, standardization to reduce discretion, and linear sequential unmasking. Laypeople think bias mitigating procedures are less useful when they perceive experts as more objective. When experts are objective, this finding is not of concern. But, in the many cases in which bias is unrecognized and difficult to overcome without procedural safeguards, resistance to mitigation procedures is notable and concerning.
